labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on the contraction 'I've' (I have), appearing in nearly all examples at high activation values. The pattern is consistent across diverse contexts including product reviews, personal narratives, technical discussions, and interviews, suggesting the feature specifically detects this common first-person discourse marker regardless of domain.

labels.label: Visibility and visual perception language
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on words and phrases related to seeing, visibility, and visual perception (see, visible, sight, noticeable, exposed, light up, glow, invisible, etc.). The pattern is remarkably consistent across all 20 examples, with the feature responding to both direct mentions of visual perception and contextual discussions about whether something can or cannot be observed.

labels.label: Animal feeding and prey behavior
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on text describing how animals eat, hunt, or search for food—including specific prey types, feeding strategies, and behavioral patterns related to food acquisition. The activation spans diverse contexts from seals and auks to elephants and insects, suggesting the feature detects the semantic concept of animal feeding behavior rather than specific species.

labels.label: Article headline transition markers
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on transitional phrases like 'READ MORE:', 'Also read:', and 'Also Read:' that typically appear before or after article headlines and related links in web content. These markers signal shifts between article sections or related story references in news and blog articles.

labels.label: Large monetary amounts and spending figures
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on contexts containing substantial dollar or pound amounts (typically in millions or billions), often preceded by verbs like 'spent,' 'invested,' 'donated,' or 'cost.' The feature appears to detect the presence of large financial figures as a semantic/numerical pattern rather than any particular sentiment or domain.

labels.label: Temporal transitions and biographical milestones
labels.explanation: This feature activates on phrases marking significant life events and temporal shifts in biographical narratives, particularly those using temporal markers like 'In [year]', 'at age', and 'from/to' constructions that denote career transitions, appointments, or major life changes. The pattern is strongest with specific dates and professional/institutional transitions in historical biographical text.

labels.label: Affirmative acknowledgment and discourse markers
labels.explanation: This feature activates on conversational affirmations and clarifying phrases like 'Right', 'That's right', 'That is', and 'What's more' that serve as agreement signals or transitional markers in dialogue and expository text. The pattern suggests the model is detecting tokens that acknowledge previous statements or pivot to new points in ongoing discourse.

labels.label: Numerical changes and percent/dollar comparisons
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts containing quantitative comparisons, percentage changes, and financial metrics (e.g., 'fell 75.91 points', 'jumped 350 per cent', 'down $60 billion', 'surged $21.30'). It appears to detect tokens within sentences that express numerical deltas, financial movements, or statistical comparisons across different time periods or categories.

labels.label: Scientific figure captions and color-coded data
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on academic and scientific text containing descriptions of visualizations with color-coded elements (blue, green, red, black lines/curves representing different data series or atmospheric/physical models). The activations are highest in contexts describing figure panels, graphs, and their colored components in technical/scientific papers.

labels.label: Negation and contrastive statements
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on sentences containing negations ("not", "no", "doesn't") and contrastive structures that set up negative claims or denials. The pattern appears particularly sensitive to negations that introduce exceptions, clarifications, or corrective statements within longer passages.

labels.label: Self-referential group identity statements
labels.explanation: This feature activates on phrases where speakers identify themselves as part of a group or category ("those who", "one of those", "I'm not a guy who", "someone who"). It captures self-descriptive statements that establish the speaker's membership in or relationship to broader social/behavioral categories.

labels.label: Multiple factors or components enumeration
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly when text describes something as composed of multiple parts, factors, or elements—commonly appearing near phrases like 'number of', 'several', 'multiple', 'combination of', or 'mix of'. The pattern reflects discourse that breaks down complex concepts into constituent parts.

labels.label: Narrative arrival and location transition
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on narrative moments describing characters arriving at or entering specific locations (Emerald City, Earth, hospital, lake, studio, etc.), as well as temporal transitions like 'when they arrived' or 'once inside'. It captures the linguistic pattern of spatial-temporal transition points in storytelling.

labels.label: Code syntax and technical documentation
labels.explanation: This feature activates on diverse code snippets and technical content including shell commands, SQL, Swift/iOS code, C++, Docker configurations, and URLs from wikihow/technical sites. The pattern suggests activation on densely packed technical syntax with special characters, operators, and structured code patterns rather than natural language.

labels.label: Numbers at start of lines or sequences
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on tokens that are numbers (particularly two-digit numbers like 10, 15, 100, 109, 150, 151, 1993) appearing at or near the beginning of text segments, contexts, or numbered lists. The consistent activation across diverse content (sports stats, airport data, monetary amounts, dates, assembly code, references) suggests the feature detects the numerical token itself rather than semantic content, likely marking structural elements like line numbers, enumeration markers, or leading numeric identifiers.

labels.label: Conditional ability/possibility statements
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on phrases expressing conditional capability or possibility, particularly constructions like 'if you/we can [verb]', 'if it can [verb]', and 'if [subject] can [action]'. The pattern reflects conditional statements about what is achievable or feasible given certain circumstances.

labels.label: Technical documentation and code snippets
labels.explanation: This feature activates on passages containing technical content like command-line arguments, Python plotting code, SSL certificates, and technical documentation with parameters and syntax. The pattern suggests sensitivity to formal technical language mixed with structured code examples and system-level configuration.

labels.label: Citation brackets and reference markers
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on citation brackets like [38][39][40], [91], [56][57], and similar reference markers commonly found in Wikipedia and academic articles. The feature appears to detect the pattern of bracketed numbers used for inline citations and footnotes in formal written text.

labels.label: Iran nuclear deal and nuclear policy discourse
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on text discussing nuclear agreements, particularly the Iran nuclear deal, as well as broader nuclear weapons policy, disarmament efforts, and nuclear testing. The consistent appearance of 'Iran nuclear deal/program' and 'nuclear' alongside political figures and policy debates indicates the feature detects discourse about international nuclear agreements and their political implications.

labels.label: Temporal references and date mentions
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on years, dates, and temporal phrases (2013, 2015, 2016, 2019, 'As of', 'since', 'January', etc.), particularly in documentary or informational text contexts. The pattern suggests the feature detects explicit time markers and temporal framing language commonly used in factual writing.

labels.label: Epistemic uncertainty and incomplete knowledge
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text expressing that something remains unknown, unexplained, unresolved, or is still in development—capturing statements about the limits of current understanding or knowledge gaps. The repeated patterns of 'remains,' 'still,' 'unknown,' and 'unexplained' across diverse contexts (scientific, political, philosophical) indicate sensitivity to expressions of epistemic humility or acknowledged ignorance.

labels.label: Positive evaluative adjectives in reviews
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on positive descriptive language like 'great', 'perfect', 'good', and 'excellent' that appears in review or recommendation contexts. The pattern suggests the feature detects sentiment-bearing adjectives used to praise items, experiences, or media.

labels.label: Dates and temporal event references
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on tokens containing or immediately following specific dates (e.g., 'January 11, 2014', 'November 15', 'September 12, 2016'), particularly when dates are associated with scheduled events, meetings, or news items. The consistent pattern across examples suggests the feature detects date tokens or date-adjacent context in informational/news-like text.

labels.label: Forum metadata and structural formatting
labels.explanation: This feature activates on forum post metadata patterns including user activity/merit indicators, post timestamps, quote attributions, and announcement/category tags like [ANN] and [Pool]. It appears to detect the structural elements and metadata formatting common in discussion forum markup rather than semantic content.

labels.label: Transitional phrases and discourse markers
labels.explanation: This feature activates on conjunctions, conditional statements, and transitional language that connect ideas or introduce new information (e.g., 'If', 'When', 'but', 'Related Posts'). However, the heterogeneous nature of examples—including proper nouns, technical content, and unrelated passages—suggests the feature may be capturing a broader pattern related to structural or boundary-marking tokens rather than a single coherent semantic concept.

labels.label: Time durations and fractional measurements
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on tokens containing time spans (1-1/2 hours, 4-5 hours, next 10 to 15 years) and fractional quantities (1/2, 1/4-1/3, one-fifth, one-tenth). The pattern suggests the model is identifying numerical expressions that represent durations or proportional measurements.

labels.label: Legal and institutional procedural language
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text containing formal legal proceedings, court actions, constitutional references, and institutional decision-making processes (motions, appeals, immunity claims, legislative procedures). The pattern suggests it detects discourse about how formal systems process, review, and adjudicate matters through established procedures.

labels.label: Public gatherings and crowd scenes
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text describing crowds, gatherings, and people assembling in public spaces—whether for protests, vigils, stadium gatherings, or emergency scenes. The pattern captures moments where groups of people congregate, often with institutional or law enforcement presence nearby.

labels.label: Transition to new narrative or topic
labels.explanation: This feature activates on sentence boundaries and discourse transitions, particularly at points where the text shifts to introduce new information, speakers, or subjects (e.g., 'Indeed.', 'Next week,', 'We're getting'). The pattern suggests the model is tracking segmentation markers between discrete narrative units or conversational turns.

labels.label: Instructional procedural steps and directives
labels.explanation: This feature activates on imperative language that guides users through sequential tasks, particularly phrases like 'Go to', 'Select', 'Change', 'Add', and 'Do' in tutorial or how-to documentation. The activation pattern is consistent across software development guides (Django, Android), design tools (Illustrator), and system configuration instructions.

labels.label: Conditional variation and contextual dependence
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on language expressing that outcomes, characteristics, or procedures vary based on conditions, contexts, or individual circumstances. The pattern consistently appears with phrases like 'varies/vary', 'depends/depending on', and 'differ according to', indicating the model has learned to recognize statements about conditional or context-dependent variation.

labels.label: Positive reactions to decisions or announcements
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts where people, organizations, or groups express approval, welcome, or positive sentiment toward decisions, announcements, or events. The pattern includes phrases like 'welcomed the decision/court's action', 'pleased with', and positive characterizations of significant announcements or changes.

labels.label: Institutional/organizational attribution phrases
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on phrases that attribute statements, actions, or information to institutional bodies (government agencies, universities, organizations, military units). The pattern centers on constructions like 'Officials from X', 'Researchers from Y', 'Spokesman for Z', and 'Troops from W' that establish institutional source attribution in news/factual contexts.

labels.label: Statistical data and numerical comparisons
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contexts containing numerical statistics, percentages, ratios, and comparative data points, often from research papers, surveys, or factual reports. The activation pattern suggests the model is identifying dense quantitative information and statistical claims that require precise numerical interpretation.

labels.label: Mathematical notation and LaTeX formatting
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on LaTeX mathematical expressions, including \displaystyle formatting, mathematical symbols (ℵ, ℜ, ∂, λ), and mathematical notation patterns like subscripts and set theory symbols. It also shows some activation on structured code/markup contexts, suggesting it responds to highly formatted, dense symbolic content.

labels.label: Academic citations and references
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on academic citation patterns, including author names followed by years (e.g., 'et al., 2011', 'Keller 2015'), bibliographic formatting, and reference list entries. The pattern strongly indicates detection of scholarly citation syntax across diverse academic fields.
labels.alternate_interpretation: Could also be described as 'formal attribution patterns' or 'numbered/dated source references'

labels.label: Sports player names and team affiliations
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts containing proper nouns related to professional sports, particularly player names (Will Hill, Johansen, Klingenberg, Hanifin) paired with team names and league contexts (Hamilton Tiger-Cats, Columbus Blue Jackets, Edmonton Eskimos, NHL, NCAA). It appears to detect the semantic pattern of athlete identification and biographical/statistical information in sports narrative text.

labels.label: Beginning or starting an action/task
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on phrases that mark the initiation of activities, such as 'went to work', 'set out', 'began', 'started', and 'commenced'. It appears to detect tokens that signal the start of a process or journey, particularly action verbs and their immediate context.

labels.label: References to reports, interviews, and discussions
labels.explanation: This feature activates on tokens that appear in contexts mentioning reports, papers, interviews, posts, or conversations—particularly phrases like 'a report on', 'a talk on', 'co-wrote a paper on', 'asked about', and 'conversation about'. It seems to detect discourse markers indicating referenced or cited information.

labels.label: First-person possessive references and personal anecdotes
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on tokens following 'my' or 'mine' that introduce personal possessions, relationships, or anecdotes (e.g., 'my co-host', 'my favorite', 'my dad', 'my wife'). The pattern reflects first-person narrative voice establishing personal connection or authority through ownership and experience.

labels.label: Past temporal contrast or change markers
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on words and phrases indicating past states or temporal transitions ('once', 'used to', 'formerly'), particularly when contrasting with present conditions or highlighting change over time. The pattern is consistent across diverse contexts where a previous state is explicitly referenced before describing a shift or difference.

labels.label: Statistical significance notation and p-values
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on statistical test results, particularly p-value expressions (p<0.05, p>0.05, p=0.001, etc.) and associated test statistics (t-tests, F-tests, correlations). The feature consistently fires on the characteristic notation patterns used in academic research reporting of statistical significance.
labels.notes: Pattern is highly consistent across examples with minimal noise. Activations form a tight cluster (3.47-3.84), suggesting stable feature semantics.

labels.label: Final farewell, last moments, or parting
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on language related to final goodbyes, last encounters, farewell moments, and concluding interactions—particularly in contexts of death, departure, or significant endings. The consistent presence of words like 'last', 'farewell', 'goodbye', 'final', and 'tribute' across examples indicates the feature detects semantic themes of terminal or concluding events.

labels.label: First-person perspective and introspection
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts containing first-person pronouns and reflective discourse, particularly phrases like 'I would be,' 'I'm talking,' 'I didn't think I would be,' and 'Am I reading.' It appears to capture moments where the speaker is narrating their own thoughts, actions, or internal processes.

labels.label: Comparative rankings and country lists
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly when the model encounters text listing multiple countries or entities in comparative/ranking contexts (e.g., 'behind Russia and Canada', 'including Austria, Belgium, Brazil'). The pattern reflects comparisons of nations across various metrics like size, population, wealth, or policy adoption.

labels.label: Discourse markers and connective 'that' clauses
labels.explanation: This feature responds to instances of 'that' functioning as a discourse connector or clause introducer, particularly when used to link ideas, introduce reported speech, or connect dependent clauses to independent ones. The activation pattern shows consistent triggering on 'that' in positions where it serves a structural role in connecting thoughts or providing explanatory/causal relationships in spoken or written narrative.

labels.label: Code function definitions and declarations
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on code snippets containing function/procedure definitions across multiple programming languages (Scheme, JavaScript, C++, Lisp, Python). It appears to detect the structural pattern of defining named functions with parameters and bodies, particularly at the moment a function definition begins or is being introduced.

labels.label: Repetitive template or structured list formatting
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on contexts containing repeated similar patterns, particularly templated code (bitset operations), structured lists, and formatted scheduling/event data. The activation suggests the model is detecting or processing patterns where similar structures are iterated or enumerated multiple times.

labels.label: Superlative rankings and comparative rankings
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on text containing ordinal rankings and superlatives (e.g., 'fourth-best', 'largest', 'most visited', 'second-largest', 'seventh-best'), particularly in contexts describing entities ranked by performance, size, or popularity. The pattern strongly generalizes across domains: sports rankings, company sizes, museum popularity, and technology metrics.

labels.label: Named effects, rules, and tests
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on eponymous phenomena and named concepts (Flynn effect, 21-Foot Rule, Bechdel Test, Vito Russo Test, Wheaton's Law, Koebe theorem) - particularly when they appear with their names or in contexts discussing their validity/origin. The feature seems to detect references to established named principles, guidelines, or scientific effects.

labels.label: Technical specifications and measurements
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text containing precise technical measurements, units, and specifications (e.g., transistor models, dimensions in millimeters/inches, material properties, equipment parameters). The pattern suggests sensitivity to factual, quantitative technical content across diverse domains like electronics, botany, optics, and materials science.

labels.label: Sports performance metrics and statistics
labels.explanation: The feature strongly activates on text discussing athlete performance statistics, shooting percentages, goals, and comparative performance assessments across various sports (basketball, soccer, esports, hockey, baseball). It appears to respond to contexts where specific numerical metrics or performance evaluations are being stated or analyzed.

labels.label: Advice-giving and recommendations
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on tokens related to giving, seeking, or discussing advice in various contexts (parenting, writing, psychedelics, food systems, etc.). The pattern is consistent across nearly all examples, with the word 'advice' or related phrasing appearing prominently in the context windows.

labels.label: List items with numbers and dashes
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on formatted list entries containing numbers, dashes, and parenthetical information, commonly found in sports standings, rankings, and structured data. The pattern appears particularly sensitive to numeric prefixes followed by team/player names and win-loss-tie records in formats like '(17-5-0-1)'.

labels.label: Making or crafting objects from materials
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on contexts describing the creation or manufacture of objects from raw materials or precursor substances, using verbs like 'make', 'craft', 'manufacture', 'carve', 'fashion', etc., followed by 'from' or 'out of'. The pattern appears across diverse domains: magical artifacts, game crafting, industrial processes (beer, gasoline, ethanol), and construction.

labels.label: Proper nouns and named entities
labels.explanation: The feature consistently activates on passages containing specific proper names (Vyacheslav, Jawaharlal, Kashgar, Sjogren's) and geographic/institutional references, suggesting it tracks named entity density or proper noun tokens. The activation appears strongest when multiple proper nouns or formal citations are present in close proximity.

labels.label: Assertion or claim introduction patterns
labels.explanation: This feature activates on phrases that introduce claims, assertions, or statements of fact, particularly patterns like 'it is [known/true/said/found]', 'there is [evidence/agreement]', and 'there are [reports]'. These are epistemic markers that signal the model is about to make or reference a claim that needs evaluation.

labels.label: Process steps and procedural explanations
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text describing multi-step processes, procedures, or sequential operations—whether manufacturing (assembly/packaging), technical workflows (compilation, rigging), or transactional procedures (fulfillment, payment). The activation often occurs near phrases that explain 'how something is done' or break down complex processes into their component steps.

labels.label: Leadership positions and organizational roles
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on tokens describing formal positions of authority and leadership titles (chair, co-chair, co-founder, president, chairman, director, coordinator) within organizations, committees, and institutions. The pattern is highly consistent across examples, with the feature responding to the contextual announcement or description of someone holding an official organizational role.

labels.label: Website comment section and user interaction prompts
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on boilerplate text related to comment sections, including phrases like 'Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus,' user login/registration prompts, and editorial notes about comment policies. The pattern reflects recurring website UI elements and calls-to-action for user engagement across news and content sites.

labels.label: Temporal boundaries and deadline expressions
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text containing explicit time periods, deadlines, and temporal endpoints (e.g., 'until [date]', 'ends on [date]', 'closes on [date]', 'from [date] to [date]'). The pattern captures language that marks the boundaries or limits of time-bound events, projects, or processes.

labels.label: Event schedule dates and locations
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text containing structured event information with dates (days of week, specific dates like 'Nov. 17', 'Aug 13'), times, and location names. The pattern appears to detect event listing/schedule formatting commonly found in calendars, sports schedules, and venue event announcements.

labels.label: Technical/scientific explanatory definitions
labels.explanation: This feature activates on passages that provide formal explanations or definitions of technical concepts across diverse domains (biology, physics, economics, mathematics). The pattern shows strong activation when text introduces what something is, how it works, or what it represents through educational exposition.

labels.label: Denial or negation of claims/assertions
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on statements that deny, refute, or contradict previous claims - typically introduced by phrases like 'has denied', 'didn't in fact say', 'doesn't mean', or 'is not'. The pattern captures moments where arguments are negated or disputed claims are being addressed.

labels.label: Verbs indicating evidence or demonstration
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on verbs that convey evidence, confirmation, or illustration of a point—such as 'speaks to', 'underlines', 'underscores', 'confirms', and 'supports'. These are typically used in argumentative or analytical contexts to show how facts or observations demonstrate a claim.

labels.label: Technical explanations and clarifications
labels.explanation: This feature activates on passages that provide detailed technical information, definitions, or explanations of complex concepts (blockchain systems, energy technology, medical procedures, academic topics, etc.), often appearing after introductory or transitional phrases. The pattern suggests the feature detects when text is shifting into or containing substantive technical content that elaborates on previously mentioned subjects.

labels.label: News article context and transitions
labels.explanation: This feature activates on tokens appearing in news/journalism contexts, particularly around transitional phrases, proper nouns introducing new topics, and contextual information about organizations, locations, and people in journalistic writing. The activation pattern suggests the feature responds to the structural and semantic markers typical of news reporting rather than a single coherent semantic concept.

labels.label: Educational credentials and graduation information
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on text passages containing educational background information, particularly phrases about graduating from institutions, class years, and degree details. The consistent pattern across examples shows the feature detects biographical/resume-style content focused on academic achievements and educational history.

labels.label: Temporal references and date ranges
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on explicit date mentions, time periods, and temporal markers such as "January 1", "since the start of the year", "between Jan. 1, 2005, and May 31", and similar date-based language. The pattern is highly consistent across examples, with the feature responding to both specific dates and temporal interval descriptions.

labels.label: Numerical dates, years, and model numbers
labels.explanation: The feature consistently activates on tokens containing numerical sequences like years (1985, 1990, 1995, 2000), dates (08/29/17, December 10 2011), and product/model numbers (CZ 2075 RAMI, Galaxy R8700, Nova F7200, 64GB). It appears to detect structured numerical identifiers commonly found in citations, technical specifications, and temporal references.

labels.label: Temporal spans and date range transitions
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on text describing periods of time, transitions between dates, or comparisons across temporal intervals (e.g., 'from 1971 to 1978', 'between 2010 and 2017', '15th to the 20th centuries'). It appears to detect the linguistic and contextual markers associated with time-range expressions and historical/chronological comparisons.

labels.label: List items and numbered sequences
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contexts containing numbered lists, enumerated instructions, and sequential item markers (e.g., '1', '2', '3', '13', '14'). The pattern appears to detect structured list formatting where content is organized by numbers, often preceding descriptive text or items in a sequence.

labels.label: Type annotations and generic template syntax
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on code containing C++ templates, generic type parameters, and type declarations with angle brackets (e.g., `<typename T>`, `<TSource>`, `Uint8`, `size_t`). The pattern appears to recognize formal type specification syntax across multiple programming languages including C++, C#, and domain-specific languages.

labels.label: Collaborative work and team contributions
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts describing multiple people working together on a project, including phrases about teams, collaborative efforts, contributors, and collective responsibility across different roles (designers, engineers, editors, etc.). The pattern appears to detect language emphasizing distributed authorship, team coordination, and acknowledgment of collective creative or technical work.

labels.label: Uncertainty, ambiguity, and unresolved distinctions
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on text expressing doubt, difficulty in making distinctions, or situations where multiple valid perspectives exist without clear resolution. The pattern includes phrases like 'not sure,' 'difficult to say,' 'conflicted,' 'unclear,' and contexts where the author acknowledges competing viewpoints or the impossibility of definitive answers.

labels.label: Inspirational/motivational statements and calls to action
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text expressing encouragement, belief, determination, and forward-looking aspirations—phrases like 'I will be better,' 'We can do it,' 'I believe,' and 'Let's seize it.' The pattern reflects positive, exhortative language that combines personal commitment with universal appeals to action and hope.

labels.label: Code syntax and technical documentation
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on code snippets (C#, C++, Haskell, assembly) and technical writing that contains programming syntax, API documentation, and formal type annotations. The consistent activation across diverse programming languages and technical contexts suggests the feature detects formal syntactic structures and developer-oriented content.

labels.label: Statistical notation and confidence intervals
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on statistical expressions, particularly confidence intervals (CI), odds ratios (OR), p-values, and related medical/scientific notation patterns like 'n = 110', '95%', and parenthetical statistical values. The pattern is consistent across numerous examples from academic papers and medical research contexts.

labels.label: Instructional procedural steps and conditions
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text segments containing instructional language with conditional clauses and procedural steps, typically found in how-to guides, documentation, and setup instructions. The pattern involves phrases like 'If you want to...', 'To [verb]...', and 'you must/need to...' that structure sequential or conditional actions.

labels.label: Contrastive conjunction introducing counterpoint
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on the words 'While' and 'But while' that introduce contrasting or qualifying statements that push back against or complicate a previous claim. The feature appears to detect discourse markers that signal a transition to a new perspective or exception to a stated rule.

labels.label: Current state or present situation
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on words and phrases indicating present tense or current conditions ("currently", "current", "right now"), typically appearing when describing the existing state of something as opposed to past or future states. The pattern is consistent across diverse contexts—from technical descriptions to factual statements—suggesting the feature detects temporal references to the present moment.

labels.label: Negative consequences or harmful impacts
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text discussing potential harms, damages, negative effects, or adverse consequences—whether to systems, people, reputations, or plans. The pattern consistently appears around words like 'hurt', 'damage', 'harm', 'endanger', 'strain', and 'ruin' in contexts discussing problematic outcomes.

labels.label: Future scheduled events and appearances
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on text describing planned future events, particularly when using phrases like 'scheduled to', 'expected to', 'is to', or 'slated to' followed by actions (testify, appear, arrive, conduct, etc.). The pattern captures mentions of future commitments and planned public activities across various domains (legal, sports, entertainment, politics).

labels.label: Technical/formal descriptive clauses with commas
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text containing technical or formal descriptions that use comma-separated clauses to specify properties, characteristics, or definitions (e.g., 'selective-fire, air-cooled automatic rifle', 'stratified, multistage probability survey'). The pattern reflects formal, technical writing style where multiple adjectives or descriptive phrases are chained together with commas to provide precise specifications.

labels.label: Quoted speech and dialogue markers
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on quoted dialogue, particularly on opening quotation marks and the beginning of spoken statements. The activation pattern suggests it detects conversational text and direct speech segments across various languages and contexts.

labels.label: Epistemic humility and acknowledged ignorance
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on expressions of not knowing, limited knowledge, or intellectual humility—phrases like 'don't know,' 'ignorance,' 'know nothing about,' and 'don't know much.' It captures moments where speakers or texts explicitly acknowledge gaps in their knowledge or understanding.

labels.label: News articles and political discourse
labels.explanation: This feature activates on excerpts from news articles, political commentary, and reports that contain references to organizations, political figures, or institutional entities. The activation pattern suggests the feature responds to journalistic/editorial text with a mix of proper nouns and policy discussion, though the activation values are moderate and the pattern is somewhat noisy across domains.

labels.label: Temporal transition phrases (until/when)
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on temporal connectors that mark transitions between time periods, particularly phrases like 'until [time] when' or 'in which case' that indicate a shift from one state/era to another. The pattern shows consistent activation across sentences describing historical changes, conditional scenarios, and narrative turning points.

labels.label: Medical conditions, injuries, and health complications
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text describing physical ailments, medical diagnoses, surgical procedures, and health-related setbacks across various contexts (sports injuries, diseases, disabilities, symptoms). The consistent pattern shows the model recognizing language about bodily harm, illness, and medical intervention.

labels.label: Repeated numerical values and array/list syntax
labels.explanation: This feature activates on patterns involving repeated numbers (like '117, 117', '3804, 3804', '474, 474') typically found in arrays, configuration files, and code structures, often followed by slightly modified values suggesting array initialization or numerical sequences. The activation suggests the model recognizes structural patterns common in code and configuration contexts where values are duplicated or appear in closely-related series.

labels.label: Capitalized proper nouns and branded names
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on capitalized proper nouns, brand names, product titles, and named entities (Office 365, Ekman-Larsson, HP, Armored Warfare, Durin's Day, etc.). The pattern suggests detection of initial capital letters marking specific identifiers, organizations, or formal titles within text.

labels.label: Webpage content with advertisements and metadata
labels.explanation: This feature appears to activate on fragmented web content including advertisements, navigation elements, structured data (tables, lists), and metadata markers. However, the pattern is noisy and inconsistent—the examples contain diverse content types (design patterns, character sheets, sports stats, news articles, social media) without a clear unifying semantic theme, suggesting the feature may be detecting superficial formatting patterns rather than meaningful content categories.

labels.label: First-person statements and personal declarations
labels.explanation: The feature strongly activates on sentences beginning with first-person pronouns ('I') followed by personal statements, opinions, or declarations about actions, beliefs, or experiences. This pattern appears across diverse contexts including personal narratives, advocacy statements, and subjective claims, suggesting the feature detects self-referential assertive statements regardless of their semantic content.

labels.label: Numbered lists and changelog entries
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text containing numbered lists, bullet points, and changelog/release note formats (e.g., '4. LLP Updates', 'Added...', 'Performed...'). It appears to detect structured enumeration patterns commonly found in technical documentation, patch notes, and feature lists.

labels.label: Technical content and explanatory prose
labels.explanation: This feature activates across diverse technical, instructional, and expository contexts including mathematics, programming, algorithms, and how-to explanations. The activation pattern suggests it responds to the presence of formal or technical language that provides systematic explanation or documentation rather than narrative or conversational content.

labels.label: Building and developing applications
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text discussing the process of creating, building, or developing applications across various contexts (web apps, mobile apps, frameworks, etc.). The consistent presence of words like 'building', 'developing', 'creating' paired with 'application' or 'app' indicates the feature captures discussion of application development workflows and practices.

labels.label: Technical specifications and energy measurements
labels.explanation: This feature activates on numerical values with scientific units, particularly in contexts involving energy capacity (GW, MWd/t, PJ/y, EJ/y, MeV, Mbps). The pattern strongly responds to technical specifications, measurements, and quantitative data presented with abbreviated units of measurement.

labels.label: Twitter/social media post formatting
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on Twitter post metadata patterns, particularly the combination of usernames (with @ symbols), timestamps, and account handles that typify social media content. The recurring activation on fragments containing 'Nick (@Nick_Falco) October 15, 2017' and similar date/username combinations suggests the feature detects the structural formatting of tweet headers and social media attributions.

labels.label: The word 'any' in various contexts
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on instances of the word 'any', appearing in diverse contexts (government policy, technical instructions, financial matters, sports, etc.). The feature is highly interpretable as it fires reliably whenever this common determiner appears, regardless of surrounding semantic content.

labels.label: Qualifier phrase 'some' or 'in some cases'
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on the word 'some' and related hedging/qualifying phrases that indicate partial applicability, exceptions, or conditional statements. The pattern appears across diverse contexts (medical, mathematical, social, technical) where 'some' introduces nuance or limitations to a broader claim.

labels.label: Proper nouns and named entities in news
labels.explanation: This feature activates on tokens that are part of proper nouns, titles, locations, and named entities commonly found in news articles and biographical texts. The activations cluster around references to people (Aaron Swartz, Paul, Norman Foster), places (Washington DC, Cleveland, Dallas, Boston), organizations (UN, Microsoft, DEA), and events (conventions, awards, legislation).

labels.label: Sentence openings with 'It's' contraction
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on instances where 'It's' (the contraction of 'It is') appears at or near the beginning of a sentence, typically used to introduce claims, descriptions, or narrative statements. The pattern is remarkably consistent across all 20 examples, with 'It's' serving as a sentence-initial marker for assertive or expository statements.

labels.label: Reported speech and attributions
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on instances of reported speech, particularly constructions where someone is quoted or their statement is attributed (e.g., 'told [person] that', 'said in interviews that'). The pattern captures the linguistic structure of indirect quotation and attribution phrases commonly found in journalistic and narrative contexts.

labels.label: Geopolitical threats and military tensions
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text discussing nuclear weapons threats, military provocations, and international security concerns, particularly involving Iran, North Korea, and China. The pattern captures discourse around weapons development, military buildup, and geopolitical conflict narratives.

labels.label: Uncertainty about future timing or status
labels.explanation: This feature activates on phrases indicating incomplete information, pending decisions, or unknown future outcomes—particularly constructions like 'not yet', 'currently' (in progress), 'still unknown', and 'has not been selected/decided'. It detects epistemic uncertainty about when something will happen or whether it will occur.

labels.label: Numerical data in parentheses and brackets
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on tokens within or immediately following parenthetical and bracketed numerical expressions, including percentages, confidence intervals, statistical values, and footnote references. The pattern suggests the feature detects contextual markers of quantitative data annotation and citation formatting common in academic and technical writing.

labels.label: Narrative continuation and past tense transitions
labels.explanation: The feature activates on transitional phrases and narrative moments where past tense verbs or action sequences connect ideas, often appearing at points where the text shifts to explain what happened or occurred next. Examples show patterns like 'was convinced by', 'was gunned down', 'was interred', 'was mopping' and similar connective narrative moments.

labels.label: Direct quotes and speech attribution patterns
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text segments containing quoted speech followed by or preceded by speaker attribution (names with 'said', 'told', 'explained', etc.). It captures the characteristic pattern of journalism and narrative text where direct quotes are paired with speaker identification.

labels.label: Moral/lesson/message extraction phrases
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on phrases that introduce or conclude a moral, lesson, or key message from a narrative or example (e.g., 'Moral of the story:', 'The message here is', 'lessons to be learned', 'The inference here is'). It appears to detect meta-commentary that extracts generalizable takeaways from stories or arguments.

labels.label: Direct quotes from named individuals
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on patterns where a person's name is followed by a direct quotation (often introduced by 'said'). The feature captures the structural pattern of attributed speech, particularly when a named source provides a direct quote, which is common in journalistic and news writing contexts.

labels.label: Conditional clauses with 'if that'
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on the phrase 'if that' (or 'if that's'), which introduces conditional statements or hypothetical scenarios. The pattern appears across diverse contexts—from dialogue to news reporting to technical discussions—where this phrase marks a shift to conditional logic or assumption-based reasoning.

labels.label: Technical documentation and explanatory prose
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on passages that explain technical concepts, procedures, or algorithms in formal/educational writing style—spanning code comments, mathematical explanations, programming tutorials, and technical descriptions. The common thread is expository text that breaks down complex ideas with clarifying detail rather than narrative or creative content.

labels.label: Narrative exposition and contextual setup
labels.explanation: This feature activates on transitional or expository text that introduces context, background information, or scene-setting details within narratives or procedural descriptions. The activation pattern suggests it detects passages that provide necessary setup information before main actions or conclusions, spanning technical documentation, fiction, and explanatory writing.

labels.label: Quoted or reported speech/statements
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on passages containing direct quotations, reported dialogue, or cited statements from sources (constitutional amendments, quotes from people, dialogue exchanges). The activation pattern suggests the model is detecting contexts where external voices or formal statements are being presented or referenced in text.

labels.label: Practical instructional steps and procedural guidance
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on instructional or how-to content that provides concrete, step-by-step guidance or practical advice for completing tasks (grinding cashews, replacing wheels, selecting clothing, adjusting camera angles, etc.). The activation tends to spike when the model encounters detailed procedural information with actionable recommendations or explanations of methodology.

labels.label: News source attribution and reporting verbs
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on patterns where news outlets or agencies are explicitly named and attributed with reporting actions (e.g., 'FoxNews.com reported', 'The Washington Post reports', 'CNN', 'AP news agency reported'). It captures the linguistic structure of citing external sources and journalistic attribution across diverse news organizations.

labels.label: Naming and designation of entities
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly when text introduces or describes the names of specific objects, places, concepts, or products using phrases like 'called', 'named', 'titled', 'dubbed', etc. The pattern consistently appears at the moment when a proper noun or designation is being assigned or explained in the narrative.

labels.label: Informal greeting and self-introduction phrases
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on casual conversational openings where someone introduces themselves using phrases like 'Hi, my name is...', 'Hello there', or 'Hello everyone'. The pattern captures the distinctive linguistic markers of personal introductions in informal, community-oriented contexts (forums, blogs, podcasts).

labels.label: Named entity citations in news articles
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts where named individuals (people's full names) are being cited or quoted in journalistic/news writing, particularly when their professional role or affiliation is mentioned. The pattern suggests the model recognizes the discourse structure of attributed quotes and biographical references common in news reporting.

labels.label: Sequential year sequences and numerical ranges
labels.explanation: The feature predominantly activates on consecutive sequences of years (2002-2007 range) and other numerical progressions. While the core pattern is clear from the top 16 examples, the lower-activation examples (17-19) introduce some noise, suggesting the feature may have secondary sensitivity to other sequential or tabular numerical data.

labels.label: Absence, lack, or undefined specifications
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on phrases expressing the lack of something specific, unclear boundaries, or undefined details—such as 'no specific', 'no clear', 'doesn't have', 'vague', 'non-specific', and 'no details'. It appears to detect linguistic patterns indicating incompleteness, ambiguity, or the absence of concrete information.

labels.label: Mentions of bars, pubs, restaurants, cafes
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates when the model encounters references to specific establishments like bars, pubs, restaurants, coffee shops, and similar venues, often in contexts describing locations, social activities, or incidents. The pattern is consistent across examples with high activation on explicit mentions of these business types.

labels.label: Biological secretion and molecular transfer processes
labels.explanation: The feature activates strongly on contexts describing secretion of biological materials (plasmids, proteins, cytokines, antioxidants) and transfer of genetic or molecular substances between organisms or cells. While there's a clear biological theme around molecular transport and secretion mechanisms, the inclusion of several unrelated examples (arrest, radar system, malware) suggests either noisy training data or a broader secondary pattern that reduces interpretability.

labels.label: Institutional and organizational names/citations
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on tokens following or within citations of specific institutions, organizations, government bodies, and named entities (offices, museums, universities, etc.). The pattern suggests it detects formal organizational references and proper noun phrases that appear in documentary or journalistic text.

labels.label: Emotional reactions and interpersonal offense
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts involving people taking offense, expressing negative emotions (offense, upset, perturbed, enraged, winced), or describing reactions to others' actions or statements. It captures moments of interpersonal friction, disagreement, or emotional distress in social interactions.

labels.label: Prepositions and comparative/correlative structures
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on prepositions (particularly 'to', 'in', 'to the') and comparative/correlative phrases that connect clauses or establish relationships between ideas. The pattern suggests the feature detects grammatical connectors and relational language that structure relationships between concepts or establish cause-effect and comparative statements.

labels.label: Mathematical notation with subscripts and recurrence
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on mathematical LaTeX and code containing subscripted variables with indexed notation (especially z_n, P_c^n patterns) and recurrence relations involving the form f_{n+1} = 2*z_n*f_n. The pattern appears across both formal mathematics (Mandelbrot/Julia set iterations) and numerical code (matrix operations, scientific computing).

labels.label: Remote access and viewing from distance
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on contexts describing the ability to access, view, or control something remotely or from a distance—whether through technology (apps, browsers, phones), physical observation (watching from stands/woods/helicopter), or online platforms. The pattern consistently involves the preposition 'from' paired with distance-enabling technology or physical separation scenarios.

labels.label: Concessive clauses with but/otherwise
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contrastive conjunctions ('but', 'otherwise') that introduce exceptions or qualifications to preceding statements, creating a concessive semantic relationship. The pattern appears across diverse contexts where the speaker acknowledges a limitation or caveat before continuing their point.

labels.label: Discrimination and protected characteristics
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text discussing discrimination, protected classes (race, religion, gender, sexual orientation, nationality, ethnicity), and equity/equality principles. The consistent pattern across examples shows the feature detects discourse around civil rights, anti-discrimination protections, and identity-based bias.

labels.label: Expressions of lack or absence ('no/not have')
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on phrases expressing negation or absence, particularly constructions like 'no X for Y', 'not have X for Y', or similar patterns indicating that something required or expected is unavailable or missing. The high activation on legal/institutional contexts (lawyers, filters, patching systems, judicial remedies) suggests it may specifically track negations of important resources or protections.

labels.label: Reported speech and attributed claims
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contexts where statements are attributed to named sources through reporting verbs like 'told', 'said', 'tells', 'writes', and 'joked'. It captures the linguistic pattern of indirect speech and journalistic attribution, where information is presented as coming from a specific person or entity.

labels.label: Numerical ranges and quantitative comparisons
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on text containing numerical ranges expressed with connectives like 'or', 'to', 'and', and 'as many as' (e.g., '20 or 30', '7 to 10', 'as many as 40'). It appears to detect patterns where quantities are presented as approximate ranges or multiple possibilities rather than single exact values.

labels.label: Pros and cons discourse markers
labels.explanation: This feature activates on phrases that introduce advantages or disadvantages in argumentative text, such as 'Pros of', 'biggest positives', 'chief feature', 'merit of', 'drawback of', and 'characteristic of'. The pattern captures comparative evaluation language used to structure balanced discussions of benefits and limitations.

labels.label: List items and categorical enumeration
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contexts containing formatted lists of items separated by line breaks or spaces, particularly academic institutions, dog breeds, file extensions, and language names. The activation pattern suggests the model recognizes structured enumeration and categorical organization across diverse domains.

labels.label: Contrastive statements with 'but' or 'however'
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts containing adversative/contrastive constructions, particularly those introducing a limitation, problem, or counterpoint after an initial claim (e.g., 'it is X but/however Y'). The pattern appears to detect semantic contrast or negation of expectations, which is common in evaluative, technical, and analytical writing.

labels.label: Structured, scripted, or predetermined patterns
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on language describing things that are stereotyped, scripted, predictable, well-defined, regimented, or follow fixed schemas—essentially describing rigid structures or predetermined behavior patterns. The consistent presence of words like 'stereotyped,' 'scripted,' 'predictable,' 'well-defined,' and 'choreographed' across diverse contexts indicates the feature detects meta-descriptions of formulaic or inflexible systems.

labels.label: Contrastive discourse and epistemic qualifications
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contexts containing contrastive conjunctions and hedging language ("but", "however", "even if", "that said") that introduce counterarguments, limitations, or nuanced qualifications to prior statements. The pattern reflects the model recognizing rhetorical moves that establish epistemic caution or argumentative complexity rather than simple assertion.

labels.label: Used as X (instrumental/functional purpose)
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on phrases describing how something is used for a particular purpose or function, specifically when preceded by 'used as' or 'used to' constructions. The pattern captures instrumental descriptions where an object or entity serves a specific functional role.

labels.label: Attribution phrases and quoted commentary
labels.explanation: This feature activates on patterns where someone is quoted or their statement is introduced, typically using phrases like 'said of', 'described as', or 'said about' that attribute statements to specific people. The feature appears to detect the structural pattern of citation/attribution followed by quoted content or commentary in text.

labels.label: Sports career setbacks and injuries
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text describing athlete injuries, missed games, career interruptions, and physical setbacks. The pattern is consistent across multiple sports contexts (football, baseball, basketball, Australian rules football) where players experience ACL tears, hamstring injuries, waivers, and limited playing time due to health issues.

labels.label: Quantitative estimates and statistical claims
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on passages containing numerical estimates, projections, and statistical claims from various authoritative sources (EPA, CDC, studies, organizations). The pattern shows activation specifically when introducing or presenting quantified predictions or measurements of magnitude.

labels.label: Violent injury or death by external force
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on descriptions of people being killed, injured, or harmed by external agents (stabbed, shot, hit, struck, blown up, crushed, etc.). The pattern is remarkably consistent across examples ranging from high to lower activations, capturing violent trauma narratives regardless of context or specific mechanism.

labels.label: Conditional statements with potential consequences
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on 'If' clauses that introduce conditional scenarios with significant outcomes or consequences (approvals, convictions, policy changes, etc.). The pattern reflects the model's detection of consequential hypothetical reasoning, where an initial condition determines a substantive result.

labels.label: Separate/Separately - Distinct entities or compartments
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on the word 'separate' or 'separately' and its contextual uses, appearing in contexts where something is divided, compartmentalized, or kept distinct from something else (separate paths, sacks, entrances, licenses, etc.). The feature reliably detects this common English word and concept across diverse domains.

labels.label: The word 'between' and spatial/relational positioning
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts containing the word 'between', which appears in nearly every example. The word is used in various contexts (spatial relationships, mediation, temporal gaps, routes), but the consistent pattern is the token 'between' itself serving as the primary activator, likely capturing this common preposition and its role in expressing relationships between entities.

labels.label: Lists with 'and' conjunctions
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on enumerated lists connected by 'and', particularly when listing nouns, concepts, or items in sequence (e.g., 'tigers, lions and bears', 'murder, rape and extortion', 'depression, anxiety and hypochondriasis'). The pattern shows consistent activation across diverse semantic domains whenever structured list conjunctions appear.

labels.label: Superlative comparisons and record-setting claims
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on phrases containing superlatives like 'the most', 'the highest', 'the largest', 'the lowest', and 'on record' - typically in contexts comparing statistics, records, or rankings across groups. The activation pattern is consistent across diverse factual domains (sports, weather, economics, crime statistics) where such comparative claims appear.

labels.label: Callback function patterns in code
labels.explanation: This feature activates on nested callback function syntax commonly found in JavaScript/Node.js code, particularly around error-handling patterns and asynchronous operations with `function(error, ...)` signatures. The activation also extends to generic type parameters and template syntax in C++, suggesting a broader pattern recognition of function signatures and parameter lists in code contexts.

labels.label: Direct quotation or reported speech
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on passages containing direct quotes (marked by quotation marks) or reported speech, particularly when introducing or transitioning between quoted statements. The pattern suggests the model recognizes the structural and semantic markers of dialogue attribution and quotation contexts.

labels.label: Present moment temporal references
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on phrases indicating current time or immediacy such as 'right now', 'now', 'today', 'currently', and 'as of today/current time'. The pattern captures discourse moments anchored in the present temporal frame, particularly in news and argumentative contexts.

labels.label: Character qualities and personal attributes
labels.explanation: This feature activates when the model encounters text describing what someone is like or what qualities/capabilities they possess, particularly in narrative or evaluative contexts. The pattern centers on phrases like 'he's got,' 'he has,' 'to him,' and descriptions of a person's character, abilities, or inner qualities.

labels.label: Nation magazine donation call-to-action
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on the repeated boilerplate text from The Nation magazine soliciting reader donations ("Chip in $10 or more"), which appears nearly identically across 19 of 20 examples. The consistent activation pattern suggests the model has learned to recognize this specific fundraising prompt template.

labels.label: Numerical lists with dash-separated ranges
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contexts containing numerical data formatted as lists with dashes, hyphens, or percentage ranges (e.g., '15-20%', '10-15%'), often appearing in structured data like statistics, tables, or ranked lists. The pattern is particularly strong for percentage ranges and numerically-organized tabular content.

labels.label: Reporting conditional statements and causal claims
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text containing conditional logic, causal relationships, and statements of contingency (e.g., 'conditional on A', 'stipulated that', 'attempted to', 'presents...with a dilemma'). It appears sensitive to discourse patterns that introduce constraints, dependencies, or hypothetical scenarios, particularly in formal, analytical, and journalistic writing.

labels.label: Numerical percentages and statistical comparisons
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on tokens containing or immediately following percentage values (e.g., '4.9%', '22 percent', '32%', '54.1 percent') in contexts presenting comparative statistics, survey data, or performance metrics. The consistent presence of numerical data and comparative language across examples suggests the feature detects statistical/quantitative reporting patterns.

labels.label: Casual second-person direct address to reader
labels.explanation: This feature activates on informal, conversational uses of 'you' where the speaker directly addresses the reader or listener in a colloquial, personal manner. The pattern appears across diverse contexts (advice, complaints, confessions, rhetorical statements) unified by direct second-person engagement in casual, informal discourse.

labels.label: Problem statement or challenge identification
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates when the model encounters explicit mentions of problems, challenges, or difficulties being stated or discussed. The pattern shows strong activation around phrases like 'the problem is', 'problems that', 'unsolvable problem', and similar constructions that introduce or frame a problem as a central concern.

labels.label: Numerical data in tabular/structured formats
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts containing numbers, statistics, financial data, and tabular information (contracts, scores, rankings, financial tables, sports data). The pattern suggests detection of dense numerical content often appearing in lists, tables, or structured data formats commonly found in web documents, sports statistics, financial records, and forum posts.

labels.label: Narrative descriptions of dramatic confrontations
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text describing tense interpersonal moments—physical altercations, arguments, emotional outbursts, and confrontational scenes—often in narrative or biographical contexts. The pattern suggests it detects conflict-laden storytelling where characters engage in dramatic interactions.

labels.label: Disqus comments section boilerplate text
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on the recurring phrase 'Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus' and related Disqus comment system boilerplate that appears across multiple web pages. The pattern suggests the model has learned to recognize this common website UI element and embedded tracking/scripting code.

labels.label: Event date ranges and temporal specifications
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on text containing date ranges, event scheduling information, and temporal markers (e.g., 'Feb. 18 to 22', 'Nov 27 to 30', 'April 15-16'). The pattern is highly consistent across examples, capturing the model's recognition of formatted event duration specifications commonly found in event announcements and festival descriptions.

labels.label: Structural discourse markers and section transitions
labels.explanation: This feature activates on punctuation and transitional phrases that mark document structure, academic organization, and quote/section boundaries (periods before new sections, 'Section V', quote attributions like 'said'). The pattern suggests detection of formal document segmentation and speaker attribution markers rather than semantic content.

labels.label: Temporal distance expressions with 'been'
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on phrases describing elapsed time using the pattern "It's/it's been [duration] since [event]", detecting the grammatical structure and semantic content of temporal retrospective statements. The feature appears specialized for recognizing narrative reflection on time passages, whether measured in years, months, or other time units.

labels.label: Song titles in quotation marks
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates when encountering song titles enclosed in quotation marks or single quotes within music-related text. The activation pattern is highly consistent across examples where song titles like 'American Girl', 'Last Goodbye', 'Over the Rainbow', and 'Run this Town' appear in quoted form.

labels.label: Structured list/outline formatting with categories
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text containing hierarchical lists, specifications, or categorical breakdowns typically found in documentation, wiki-style entries, or structured content. The pattern appears sensitive to lines that are part of organized enumerations or categorical headers followed by subcategories or bullet points.

labels.label: Numerical data and citations
labels.explanation: This feature activates on contexts containing numerical sequences, citations, dates, statistical data, and technical specifications. The pattern appears to detect tokens in academic, technical, or data-rich passages where precise numerical information is present or referenced.

labels.label: Firefox browser references and mentions
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on mentions of Firefox, the web browser, appearing across diverse contexts including technical documentation, privacy discussions, and comparisons with other browsers. The consistent high activations on 'Firefox' tokens and related Firefox-specific content (about:config, Tor Browser, Mozilla patches) indicate the feature has learned to recognize this specific software product.

labels.label: Intensifying adverb 'so' in consequence clauses
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on the intensifier 'so' used in constructions like 'so [adjective] that' or 'so [verb] that', where it emphasizes degree or intensity leading to a consequence. The pattern appears across diverse contexts (impressive demonstrations, emotional states, technical properties) unified by the grammatical structure of degree-consequence relationships.

labels.label: Physical objects with text or markings
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on mentions of tangible items that contain, display, or are labeled with written content—such as cards, notes, letters, plaques, napkins, stamps, files, and packages. The pattern suggests the model is detecting descriptions of concrete objects being used as containers or vehicles for text/information.

labels.label: Comparative statements and product contrasts
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts containing comparative language, contrasts between products/services, or statements about what companies are doing differently (e.g., 'instead of', 'Compare that to', 'moving away from'). The pattern suggests the feature detects discourse that explicitly juxtaposes alternatives or highlights distinctions between entities.

labels.label: Uncertainty and unknowing expressions
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on phrases expressing uncertainty, confusion, or lack of knowledge, particularly phrases containing 'know/knows what's', 'not sure', 'don't know', and 'nobody knows'. The pattern is consistent across diverse contexts (politics, technology, personal situations) but unified by the semantic theme of epistemic uncertainty.

labels.label: Signing/submitting formal agreements or documents
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts involving formal agreements, contracts, and official submissions—words like 'signed,' 'deal,' 'contract,' and 'submit' appear across nearly all examples. The feature appears to detect language associated with legal or administrative commitments and formal document submission.

labels.label: Comparative assertions and agreement statements
labels.explanation: This feature activates on tokens within comparative or concessive statements, particularly those introducing agreement, contrasts, or evaluative claims (e.g., 'agree that', 'more than', 'is actually', 'can be shown that'). The pattern suggests the feature detects discourse markers signaling epistemic claims or argumentation transitions.

labels.label: Personal data collection and privacy breaches
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly when text discusses the collection, disclosure, or exposure of personal information such as addresses, social security numbers, IP addresses, financial details, and other identifying data. The pattern reflects contexts discussing privacy violations, data tracking, or sensitive information management.

labels.label: Author/source attribution and bylines
labels.explanation: This feature activates on text patterns where individuals are identified by their professional role, affiliation, or credentials, typically appearing in author attributions, bylines, or source citations (e.g., 'X is a journalist/professor/author'). The pattern is consistent across news articles, academic content, and journalistic sources where credentials establish authority or context.

labels.label: Foreign words/phrases with translations in parentheses
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly when the model encounters foreign language terms or phrases immediately followed by English translations in parentheses. The pattern appears across multiple languages (French, Chinese, Spanish, Dutch, German, Greek, Hebrew) and consistently marks the structure of 'foreign term' (translation) appearing in text.

labels.label: Spatial relationships and geographic distance
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on text describing locations separated by distance—'other side of', 'across', 'between', directional references ('east of', 'western side'). It captures language expressing geographic separation, traversal, or opposing positions in space.

labels.label: Identifying groups most affected by adverse events
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on phrases describing which populations or regions are most impacted by negative circumstances (unemployment, natural disasters, policy changes, disease), particularly when using phrases like 'hardest hit', 'most at risk', or 'most vulnerable'. The pattern indicates the model recognizes semantic structures identifying affected groups or demographics.

labels.label: News announcements and official statements
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on contexts where organizations, institutions, or public figures make formal announcements or statements to the media. The pattern is consistent across governmental bodies, corporations, sports organizations, and public figures using language like 'announced that', 'it was announced', or 'news that' followed by official declarations.

labels.label: Physical addresses and location specifications
labels.explanation: This feature consistently activates on street addresses, building locations, and geographical coordinates presented in a structured format (street number, street name, city, postal codes). It appears to detect when the model is processing concrete location information that identifies specific places.

labels.label: Compliance with rules and procedures
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on text discussing adherence to laws, regulations, protocols, and official procedures (words like 'comply', 'abide', 'accordance', 'follow', 'obey', 'enforce'). The pattern spans both abstract policy discussions and concrete procedural contexts, suggesting the feature detects language about conforming to established rules and authority structures.

labels.label: List items separated by punctuation or symbols
labels.explanation: This feature activates on sequences containing repeated list-like patterns with separators such as periods (file extensions), dashes (organizational lists), 'Y' connectors (legislative records), or line breaks with numbered entries. The common thread is enumerated or categorical data presented in a dense, structured format with consistent delimiters between items.

labels.label: Time of day expressions and schedules
labels.explanation: This feature strongly activates on explicit time mentions in the format of clock times (e.g., '5 a.m.', '4am', '3 p.m.', '10:30pm'), particularly when describing daily schedules, work hours, or event timings. The pattern is consistent across narratives about morning wake-up times, business hours, and event scheduling.

labels.label: Superlative phrases with 'the' and emotional intensity
labels.explanation: This feature activates strongly on phrases using superlative constructions (the best/worst/most/greatest/easiest thing/person in the world) that express extreme emotional sentiment. The pattern suggests the feature detects hyperbolic, emotionally-charged language that emphasizes extremes through superlative grammatical structures.

labels.label: Numeric literals and comma-separated values
